comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I think we have a date 5/9/91 - 5th September 1891 - it was a Saturday. And thanks to Trove, it was the Arrival of the (first?) Australian Auxiliary Fleet. Seven ships - KATOOMBA, TAURANGA, and WALLAROO in one line, and RINGAROOMA, MILDURA, BOOMERANG, and KARRAKATTA in another line. Very full details SMH 7/9/1891 p.8 (other relevant articles also on same page) - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13837805

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Background history to "Australia's First Fleet", ship details and crew names, enough for any maritime historian - SMH 5/9/1891 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13837652

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Wow thanks Beachcomber! Didn't realise it was 'Australia's First Fleet' - what an important moment in our history :) Very happy to have identifited the occasion.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] It's a bit strange.  This occasion was of great importance at the time (1891) to Australia and NSW,  but seems to be forgotten now.  Probably more related photos will turn up now that we are conscious of the event.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Hopefully! Will see if we can find anymore possibilities in our collection...
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] In fact this image is likely to be of the same event. Same date & same collection.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] Hmmm - sorry to disagree,  but the 1893 Garden Island sheerlegs are visible in that photo,  so it must be later than this one.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Ahh well, back to the drawing board re the first fleet...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Now even more puzzled! Why was this occasion not even mentioned in the current 2013 Fleet Review? It was very definitely an Australian Squadron, even paid for by Australian taxes, the seven warships forming "The Nucleus of a Navy" trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13837652

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Hmm perhaps because it was pre-1911 (and pre-1913), but then they did have early material too... Not sure? As that article states: "The construction of the Australian Squadron has come about and we are at last placed in an independent position, able to defend ourselves with our own vessels". A significant day.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons
